results.title: Extreme art 2
results.brief_description: Further explorations in experimental music video from Western Europe. As in the first collection of “Extreme Art”, these industrial-electronic musicians use sound and images heavily influenced by European surrealism. In this volume many of the contributions show the influence of the acid- house music scene, with a greater use of sampling in the music and a greater reliance on computer animation in the video imagery. The collection spans across punk, industrial music, heavy metal and house to deliver music at the edge of chaos.

results.title: Extreme art
results.brief_description: This is a collection of Western European experimental music videos. Featuring collaborations between electronic composers and avant-garde image-makers, the artists in “Extreme Art” all share a commitment to an artistic expression the roots of which are to be found in surrealism and dada. The visual work combines computer animation, video collage, and super-8 film to present a menacing vision of technological society at the point of implosion. The music in this video ranges from minimalist electronic experimentation to bizarre combinations of indigenous ethnic music with computer simulated noise; to brooding, menacing industrial soundscapes. Though the artists represented in this music video sampler are all unique from one another, they are all uncompromising in their desire to produce work which unsettles and disturbs. NOTE: SOME OF THE VIDEO IMAGERY MIGHT BE DISTURBING. DO NOT ADJUST YOUR SET - SOME VIDEO SEGMENTS ARE DELIBERATELY UNSTABLE.

results.title: Expo 67 explore!
results.creator_credit: Vincent Vaitiekunas, Crawley Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Anyone bent on really remembering happy days at Montreal’s world’s fair, Expo 67, is likely to agree that this film is it. In a brief quarter-hour it explores most of the fair at a friendly, unhurried pace, with many a pause to smile and enjoy. It will please anyone who saw Expo, and even more, those who missed the opportunity to be there themselves. No dialogue, musical background only.

results.title: Exploring our solar system
results.creator_credit: Sidney Platt and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: This video explores the Milky Way from the center to its outer limits using computer enhanced footage from NASA and specially commissioned animation based on information obtained during Voyager 2’s flyby of Neptune in 1989. Beginning with the Sun, each of the main features of the planets is described, including the earth and our moon. A description of the ways in which the solar system is investigated, including telescopes and manned and unmanned space travel is also included. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teachers guide included.

results.title: Exploring occupational health and safety
results.brief_description: Trainers and occupational health and safety managers will welcome this training package for employees which has been made in Australia expressly for Australasian conditions. Aimed particularly at the induction level employee, it is equally useful as a general refresher program or as an educational introduction to occupational health and safety. Hosted by Margaret Throsby, the issues covered by the program include management and employee responsibilities under the new legislation; the role of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission; factors contributing to major health and safety problems such as RSI; functions of safety committees, quality circles and industrial democracy; and legal safety standards.

results.title: Explorations: wrestling
results.creator_credit: Claude Fournier, Claude Jutra, Marcel Carriere, Michel Brault, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A candid-camera view of professional wrestling as seen in the Montreal Forum, where some of the biggest bouts are staged, and in back-street wrestling parlors where the warriors practice their art. Nothing escapes the probing camera as well-muscled tyros grapple, punch, squirm, roar and grimace, adding their own variations of showmanship to amuse and excite the crowd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Claude Fournier, Claude Jutra, Marcel Carriere, Michel Brault, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Experienced hands: a study in continuing education
results.creator_credit: Theodore Conant, Elspeth Chisholm, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The story of the Quo Vadis School of Nursing in Toronto, which trains older women - most of them housewives and mothers - to become graduate nurses. They help to alleviate the shortage of nurses, and Toronto hospitals welcome their mature presence in the wards. This film describes the project during its first experimental year.

results.title: Experiment in romance
results.creator_credit: Robert Sdraulig and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Clive, an insulated academic, gets a taste of “La Dolce Vita”. What happens subsequently is limited only by his imagination. Cast includes: Marie-Louise Walker, James Reyne and John Howard. Camera by Michael Bladen.

results.title: Expectations - a Story about Stress (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This program aims to help pre-adolescents recognise and deal with stress which, according to experts, is the underlying cause of 75% of all illness and disease among children. The video follows the stories of two children, both gymnasts in the school team trying to cope with the expectations and pressures of parents. One child is pushed to perform to the exclusion of all else, and the other child has conflicting demands placed on her.

results.title: Expanding classroom: Elizabethan village
results.creator_credit: Eileen Molony, G Inger, British Broadcasting Corporation and Worcestershire Education Authority
results.brief_description: The pupils of the senior class at Ashton-under-Hill Primary School reconstruct life in Elizabethan times - constructing wattle-and-daub walls, weaving rush mats, cooking Elizabethan dishes, playing Tudor music, writing with quill pens, writing and giving their own interpretation of witches’ spells, and collecting herbs.
